tossups.answer: Gabriel García Márquez [prompt on Marquez] <Tom> Bonuses:

answers: “What We Talk About When We Talk About Love”
cardiologist [accept heart surgeon, prompt on less specific medical professions] <LC>
parts: Name this short story, in which four friends in Albuquerque sit around a table drinking gin. Somehow they come onto the topic of the title concept, which may or may not be an absolute.
This author of “What We Talk About When We Talk About Love” was nominated for the National Book Award and the Pulitzer Prize for Fiction for his third major-press collection, Cathedral.

In the story, Mel McGinnis holds this specific profession, which sometimes “gives him the right”. After getting his words muddled, he elaborates that “I’m just a mechanic. I go in and I fuck around and I fix things.”

answers: Foramen of Magendie [accept median aperture or medial aperture] <DJL>
parts: Name this substance that provides mechanical and immunological protection to the brain. A sample can be obtained via a lumbar puncture.
CSF fills these interconnected cavities in the brain, which are continuous with the central canal of the spinal cord. They share their name with a type of chamber in the heart.
CSF drains from the fourth ventricle to the cisterna magna of the subarachnoid space via this opening, often named for a French physiologist.

This goddess’s role as another deity’s lover is decidedly reluctant, but she ate several pomegranate seeds so she has to stay half the year in the Underworld. She even had to share her own lover, Adonis, with Aphrodite.
This lover of Eos [EY-os] supposedly aged into a cicada since Eos forgot to ask for eternal youth along with the immortality bestowed on this Trojan prince.

Apollo was so furious when this lover of his fell in love with the mortal Ischys that he forgot that having Artemis kill her would also kill this woman’s unborn son Asclepios, though Hermes managed to save him.

answers: palmistry or chiromancy [accept any description involving palms]
Tesseography [accept any description involving tea leaves, coffee grounds, or wine sediments] <LC>
parts: In this divining technique, it was hoped that a depicted figure’s association with astrology would help predictions. It became popular in Europe in the 14th century and typically uses a set of 52 images.
A school of this technique was established in London by William John Warner. Readings can be taken by tracing lines and mounts, as well as identifying dermatoglyphics.
The first use of this technique is traced back to 229 BC when a princess rejected astrological predictions in favour of interpreting the colours of sedimentary symbols.

This Ukrainian-Canadian pianist is known for pioneering “continuous music” on works such as his album KMH. He holds several speed-playing world records, including sustaining an average of 14 notes per second for a full hour.

This other piano composer used free time for his five hour unfinished magnum opus, The Well-Tuned Piano. This minimalist also founded the Theatre of Eternal Music, whose members included Terry Riley and John Cale.
This Parisian composer was amongst the first in the Western tradition to avoid using bar-lines or time signatures, in works such as his Gnossiennes and Gymnopédies.

answers: Lord Woolf [or Harry Kenneth Woolf; Baron Woolf] <ADG>
parts: Name these written orders from an administrative or judicial body, which dominated the procedure of English common law until the abolition of forms of action in the 1830s.

Responsibility for issuing writs originally lay with this English Officer of State, although that power was curtailed by the Provisions of Oxford. This office was amalgamated with Secretary of State for Justice in 2007.

The wide-ranging 1998 legal reforms named for this Master of the Rolls renamed many prerogative writs and created the modern British Civil Procedure Rules. He also led the enquiry into the 1990 Strangeways prison riot.

answers: The Laocoön Group / Laocoön and his Sons <JK>
parts: Name this French sculptor, who included that work alongside The Thinker and The Kiss in his ensemble The Gates of Hell.

Rodin’s version of Ugolino and his Sons may have been inspired by a sculpture of the same story by this other 19th-century French sculptor. In this man’s version, Ugolino is depicted seated, and gnawing at his fingers.

The composition of Carpeaux’s Ugolino and his Sons is itself inspired by this ancient sculpture, depicting a Trojan priest and his family. It was excavated near Rome in 1506 and is attributed to Athenodorus, Agesander, and Polydorus.

This island group is nominally owned by Norway, but, according to the Spitsbergen Treaty of 1920, citizens of any signatory nation, including Russia and the USA, have access to the archipelago and its resources.

This settlement is the capital of Svalbard and its largest town. It is named after an American miner and its population is surprisingly multinational - 16% is non-Norwegian, including a substantial Thai minority.

One area where all the signatories of the Treaty agree on Svalbard’s use is science. As well as many glaciers and smaller ice caps, it contains this ice cap, the largest by area in Europe, making it of great interest to glaciology.

answers: Quadratic residue [prompt on partial answer, or attempted descriptions]
Convexity [accept words forms; prompt on concave upward early, but not just concave] <JK>
parts: Legendre’s name is perhaps most associated with a set of polynomials with this property, which means that the integral of any two distinct Legendre polynomials from -1 to 1 is zero, if one interprets the integral as an inner product.
The Legendre symbol is a multiplicative function, usually written [open bracket] a over p [close bracket], where p is an odd prime. It takes the value 1 if a is a non-zero one of these values mod p.

The Legendre transformation of a function will always have this property. Functions have this property if their second derivative is everywhere non-negative, and this property is sometimes called ‘concave upward’.

answers: Five-Year Plans for the Development of the National Economy of the Soviet Union [or Pyatiletki]
the New Economic Policy [or Novaya Ekonomicheskaya Politika]
Aleksei Grigoryevich Stakhanov [also accept the Stakhanovite Movement] <LC>
parts: This name is given to Joseph Stalin’s proposals for developing the Soviet economy. The first ran from 1928 to 1932 with the hope of promoting “Socialism in One Country,” but resulted in widespread, devastating famines.

Stalin devised the first Five-Year Plan to replace this program of limited free markets instituted by Lenin and championed by Nikolai Bukharin. It enacted the prodnalog agricultural tax and resulted in the Scissors Crisis.

During the second five-year plan, this man inspired a propaganda cult after allegedly mining 102 tons of coal in under 6 hours. His model and namesake “movement” was used to offer bonuses to exemplary workers.

answers: Terence [accept Publius Terentius Afer; prompt on partial]
parts: Name this Roman playwright, a freed slave who inspired Moliere’s A School for Husbands with his play Adelphoe. His other works include The Eunuch and The Self-Tormentors.

This play by Terence was the first of his to be performed. At the beginning of this play, Chremes revokes permission for Pamphilus to marry Glycerium, the title character, after the former acts up at a funeral.

This Renaissance writer first ventured into the theatre by adapting Terence’s Andria for the Florentine stage. His later plays include The Mandrake, though he is perhaps better known for political treatises like The Prince.

answers: Laue’s condition [accept Bragg’s Law which may be demonstrated as functionally equivalent] <YY>
parts: Give this letter, commonly used to denote momentum space. It is also used as the symbol for Boltzmann's constant, as well as the SI unit of temperature.
The first one of these regions are defined as the Wigner-Seitz cell of the reciprocal lattice: the locus of points which are closest to a given reciprocal lattice point than any other.

This condition states that in elastic scattering, the incident and scattered momentum vectors differ by a reciprocal lattice vector. That is to say that the projection of the primitive vector onto the scattering vector must equal two pi times the relevant Miller index.

Name this play by Mike Bartlett, which premiered at the Almeida Theatre in 2014. In this play, the Republican Jess convinces Harry to renounce his family name, and the Duchess of Cambridge plots her husband’s rise to power.

Mike Bartlett is also known for his adaptation of this play by Euripides, which inspired him to write the TV series Doctor Foster. This play’s title character kills her own children after her husband Jason marries Glauce.
Bartlett’s latest work is this play, inspired by The Cherry Orchard, in which Audrey yearns for a romanticised lost England whilst restoring her Oxfordshire childhood home.
Name this asset. 50 Cent’s decision to accept this asset as payment for a 2014 album has recently led to him earning millions of dollars during an unprecedented “boom” in this digital commodity.

Bitcoin is the big daddy of cryptocurrency, but not all of its dealings are above board. It is often used in online black markets such as this one founded by Dread Pirate Roberts. Its third iteration folded in 2017.

If you missed out on the Bitcoin bonanza, you could invest in this blockchain platform created by Vitalik Buterin. It features smart contract functionality for decentralised applications, and is already in use by RBS.
Name this 1919 essay, which goes on to describe the state as that which has “a monopoly on legitimate physical violence” within a territory.
‘Politics as a Vocation” is an essay by this German sociologist, who also wrote The Protestant Ethic and the Spirit of Capitalism.
In “Politics as a Vocation”, Weber argues that the practice of politics is difficult because politicians are prone to this quality, which makes them emotionally attached to their followers.

answers: the Scythians [also accept the Sakae, Massagetae, Iskuzai, or Skolotai; also accept Samatians, Alans, or Ossetians even though there is significant debate over whether those later Iranic “Scythians” are the same Scythians as the earlier ones]
parts: Name these pointy hat-wearing horsemen, who popularized the composite bow and dominated the steppes north of the Black Sea. These targets of several Achaemenid campaigns left behind tombs called kurgans.

Much of our information on the Scythians, including details about their archaeologically-verified fondness for cannabis, comes from this rather unreliable Greek historian known as the “Father of History.”

This key Scythian archaeological site, a burial in the Altai mountains, produced such discoveries as mummies of a heavily-tattooed chief and the “Siberian Ice Maiden”, as well as what is likely the world’s oldest pile carpet.

answers: Wally (accept Waldo, accept Where’s Wally? Or Where’s Waldo?)
Star Trek III: The Search For Spock [accept either underlined portion] <SC>
parts: One such person who always seems to need locating is this lanky bespectacled man with a penchant for red and white clothing, created by Martin Handford.
In an eponymous series of video games, locating where this international supervillain and head of V.I.L.E [vile] is in both space and time is a very important task for A.C.M.E [acme].
In this film, the crew of the USS Enterprise travel to the forbidden Genesis planet to locate the body of a dead crew member.

answers: The Troubles [accept the Northern Ireland conflict]
parts: A man using the pseudonym “Roy Walsh” placed a device made from an egg timer and a VCR in a bathroom in one of these places, but the person he intended to assassinate happened to be up late writing a speech.
Provisional IRA member Patrick Magee targeted Margaret Thatcher in the Brighton Hotel Bombing during this conflict. It is typically said to have ended with the Good Friday Agreement of 1998.

Journalists covering the Troubles often stayed at this “Hardboard Hotel” on Great Victoria Street, Belfast, which has suffered 36 bomb attacks since it opened in 1971. It claims to be the “most bombed hotel in Europe.”

answers: Anthony Burgess [or John Anthony Burgess Wilson] <Theo>
parts: Name this novel which describes the efforts of aging writer Kenneth Toomey to help canonise Carlo Campanati. This novel’s opening line describes Kenneth in bed with his catamite on his 81st birthday.

Toomey is said to be based upon this British “first-rate writer of the second rank”, since this man was also homosexual and interested in colonial South-East Asia. This author created Charles Strickland, a fictionalised Gauguin.
Earthly Powers is a work of this British novelist and translator who wrote the Enderby Quartet. This author also created the language Nadsat for use in his novel A Clockwork Orange.

answers: Posthumanism [also accept transhumanism and word forms; prompt on anything similar to futurism or antihumanism and word forms].
parts: Name this concept, hierarchical social structures of which are often called “patriarchy” in contemporary feminism, which seeks, among other things, to analyse and undermine the namesake “roles” of this thing.

N. Katherine Hayles, Rosi Braidotti, and the “cyborg feminist” Donna Haraway have incorporated feminism into this field, which attacks post-Enlightenment anthropocentrism. Other scholars in it focus on “the singularity.”

This pioneer of eco-feminism challenged humans’ “standpoint of mastery” and links it to patriarchal attitudes in Feminism and the Mastery of Nature. She partly credits those insights to nearly being eaten by a crocodile.

answers: Sukkot [or the Feast of the Booths; or the Feast of the Tabernacles] <HO>
parts: After the Maccabean revolt, Judas Maccabeus determined that every year the rededication of the Temple should be observed for eight days after a day of oil lasted that long, creating this Jewish festival of lights.

According to the Books of the Maccabees, this priest and father of Judas Maccabeus inspired and at first led the revolt after killing a Jew who had made a sacrifice to the pagan Gods and the Greek official enforcing it.
The “first Hanukkah” celebrated by the Maccabees was, according to 2 Maccabees, in fact a delayed observance of this festival, which heavily involves the hadass, aravah, lulav, and etrog.

answers: DEPT (or Distortionless enhancement by polarisation transfer)
parts: Name this commonly studied nucleus whose chemical shifts range from about 0 to 220 ppm.
This NMR method can be used to determine whether a given carbon atom is primary, secondary or tertiary. Depending on pulse angle, carbons bonded to different numbers of protons will become inverted.
This common solvent for NMR experiments will show up in carbon-13 NMR as a triple peak at 77 ppm.
The French princess Eugene Murat commissioned “Five Easy Pieces”, a set of piano duets by this composer. This composer wrote the Dumbarton Oaks concerto in his neoclassical phase.

“Six Easy Pieces” is the abridged version of a collection of lectures by this Caltech physicist. This physicist won the Nobel for his work on quantum electrodynamics and names diagrams used to model particle interactions.

This artist one-upped Feynman by presenting “Seven Easy Pieces” at the New York Guggenheim in 2005. Other major works by this “grandmother of performance art” have included “The Artist is Present” and “Rhythm Zero”.

answers: Madonna and Child [also accept answers like Virgin and Child, Mary and Child, or Our Lady] <JK>
parts: Name this Bruges painter, said to be the first Northern painter to master linear perspective, whose works include Virgin and Child Enthroned with Saints Francis and Jerome and Portrait of a Carthusian.
Petrus Christus’ predecessor in the Bruges school, and perhaps his teacher, was this Flemish painter who created the Ghent Altarpiece with his brother, Hubert.

Petrus Christus’ best-known depiction of this religious scene unusually takes place in the branches of a dry tree. Van Eyck’s paintings of this scene include ones named for Canon van der Paele and for Chancellor Rolin.
